contraindications precautions to test: Use of exercises with resistance is contraindicated in acute and chronic-active phases of RA; resistance can damage inflamed tissue and joints(4)
Modification of active/passive ROM testing and muscle strength testing might be necessary for joints exhibiting signs of acute inflammation(4)
Manual muscle testing (MMT) is contraindicated during acute flares(4)
The therapist should be gentle and move slowly while handling painful, swollen joints(4)
Palpation should be gentle and repeated as few times as possible
Proceed with caution when examining, palpating, or manipulating joints with skin that is fragile as a result of RA or medication side effects(4)
Patient should be positioned comfortably and fully supported during examination, and testing should be performed with as few position changes as possible
Activity should stop when the patient feels pain, fatigue, or discomfort(4)
Physician’s orders and protocol should be followed at all times(4)
Vigorous stretching and vigorous manipulative techniques are contraindicated

Document the time of day that the examination takes place, as joint stiffness and functional ability often fluctuate significantly over the course of the day(1,4) –Also note the most recent administration of pain and/or anti-inflammatory medications as this can also impact the level of function(4)

Occupational therapy evaluations for patients with RA should utilize a client-centered  approach to most effectively evaluate deficits and needs(4) –A client-centered  approach includes the following principles: -The patient is uniquely qualified to make decisions about his or her occupational functioning(4) -The patient should have an active role in determining goals and desired outcomes(4) -The patient-therapist  relationship should be interdependent -Evaluation and treatment should focus on the patient’s culture, roles, interests, etc.(4) -When the patient is able to define the problems that he or she would like to work on, the patient also becomes a problem solver(4) -The patient should evaluate his or her own performance and set personal goals(4)

pathogenesis: The clinical presentation of RA varies significantly among patients; both genetic andenvironmental factors will affect the progression, extent, and pattern of the diseasewithin a specific patient(1)

RA causes the patient’s synovial membrane to change into disorganized lymphoidgranulation tissue(1)–Both resident and infiltrating cells contribute to hyperplasia of the synovial membraneand erosion of the cartilage or bone in RA(1)

The patient’s immune system begins to attack the synovial membrane of the joints,resulting in inflammation(1)–The inflammation leads to increased heat, swelling, pain, and redness and decreasedROM in the affected joint(1)–As this inflammation continues, the synovial membrane cells multiply and create amass called a pannus(1,2)–The pannus weakens and eventually destroys the underlying cartilage of the joint(1,4)–The joint space becomes obliterated by fibrous adhesions(1)–The entire process results in continuous tissue damage(1)
Scar tissue can form between the bone ends of the joint, resulting in permanent loss ofjoint function and mobility(4)
risk factors: Age (onset can be at any age; however, prevalence increases with age)(4)
Obesity, exposure to air pollution and silica, and vitamin D deficiency may pose risk(6)

overall contraindications precautions: Special considerations required to most effectively evaluate and treat the patient with RA include increased awareness of pain, joint stiffness and deformity, fatigue, and coping strategies(4)

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: When was RA diagnosed in the patient? -Note the duration of the patient’s most recent exacerbation(s) and remission(s) -With which joint(s) does the patient have the most difficulty?(4) -If RA is not newly diagnosed, what has changed that prompted the patient to seek therapy?

course of treatment.medical management: There is no cure for RA; however, medical treatments are available for symptom management(1) Patients with joint disease often delay seeking medical care anywhere from 2 to 4 years after symptoms begin(1) RA can be difficult to diagnose in its early stages; however, early diagnosis and treatment are essential for maximizing functional outcomes(3) There is no test specifically for RA; diagnosis is based on medical history, symptomatology, physical examination, and radiographic images(3,5,34) alleviate pain and stiffness of the joints(1,4) reduce the swelling of the joints(1,4) preserve maximal joint function and muscle strength(1,4)  prevent disability and disease-related  morbidity(4) minimize adverse effects of long-term  use of medications(1,4) maintain functional status(1,4) promote normal growth and development (for children with JRA)(1) physical management (including occupational and physical therapy)(1) psychosocial management(1) nutritional therapy(1) pharmacological management(1) management of comorbidities(1) Surgery for patients with RA is indicated for severely damaged joints and includes total joint replacement; knee and hip joint replacements are associated with the most positive outcomes with respect to increased function and mobility(1,4) In addition to joint replacements, other surgical interventions for RA include arthrodesis (joint fusion), synovectomy (excision of diseased synovium), and tenosynovectomy (removal of diseased tendon sheaths)(4) Authors of a study assessing surgical intervention in a cohort of Medicare beneficiaries in whom RA was newly diagnosed found that upper extremity procedures (e.g., synovectomy, tendon reconstruction, arthrodesis) were performed earliest in the course of the disease(27)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the physician has prescribed; are they being Disease-modifying  antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs)(1) DMARDs should be started as soon as possible following diagnosis to decrease disease activity. Early diagnosis and initiation of DMARs is associated with better outcomes(31) DMARDs have greater efficacy when used in combination(2) DMARDs can be classified as synthetic or biologic(2) Synthetic DMARDs include methotrexate, sulfasalazine, leflunomide, and antimalarial drugs Biologic DMARDs include tumor necrosis factor inhibitors (TNF), abatacept, rituximab, and tocilizumab Analgesic drugs(1) NSAIDs(1,4) Corticosteroids(1,2,4) Cytotoxics(1)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Usual tests for this condition are the following:
Comprehensive medical history and physical examination by the physician(1,4)
Rheumatoid factor (RF) is an antibody found in the blood serum of approximately 85% of patients with RA; however, it can also be present with other inflammatory diseases(4)
Tests of joint fluid and/or tissue to evaluate for infections and/or inflammation(1)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack, paraffin wax) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful(4)

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors  (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, stiff, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling) -See Presenting signs and symptoms , above, for a full list of symptoms associated with the four phases of RA
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)(4) -Document the location of pain; if possible, attempt to have the patient distinguish between pain in the joint and pain in the soft tissue(4)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables(4) -Morning stiffness that lasts longer than 1 hour is a hallmark feature of inflammatory arthritis; this symptom distinguishes RA from noninflammatory arthritis (i.e., osteoarthritis)(1) -Intensity and duration of morning stiffness are used as a gross estimate of the overall severity of RA(1)
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Pain in RA can significantly impair the patient’s ability to have restful sleep;(4) document difficulty sleeping and number of wakings/night, if present
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to a physician (e.g., increased fatigue, sudden unexplained swelling, joint pain associated with fever or rash, back or neck pain) -Patients with RA (especially severe RA) are at an increased risk of anger, depression, and other psychosocial issues(1,4) -Felty’s syndrome is the occurrence of splenomegaly and neutropenia that occurs in patients with RA; present in less than 1% of patients with RA(1,2)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Note respiratory status -Patients with RA can have pulmonary involvement such as pleuritis, interstitial fibrosis, pulmonary nodules, pneumonitis, and other pulmonary obstructive diseases(1,5) -Does the patient require supplemental oxygen? Tracheostomy tube, nasal cannula, or breathing mask? -Does the patient become short of breath?(5) If so, when? Standing? Walking? With exercise? Utilize Borg Rating of Perceived Exertion (RPE) Scale for subjective measurement Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes □ No □ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Previous history of same/similar diagnosis Any prior disease or injury that resulted in reduced hand function? Any prior history of arthritis, a joint replacement, or fusion surgery (including the knee, hip, etc.), falls, etc.?(4)
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask the patient about other problems, including history of falls, diabetes, cancer, heart disease, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders Patients with RA are at an increased risk of developing lymphoma(1)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask the patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Vocation/avocation and associated repetitive behaviors, if any -What are the patient’s occupations and role(s) within his or her family?(1,4) -The Role Checklist and the Worker Role Inventory are appropriate measures for patients with RA(3) -Is patient currently employed? If so, is the patient currently able to work without difficulty? If not, planning to return to work?(1) -What activities, hobbies, etc., does the patient enjoy? What is the patient’s current and prior level of activity?(1,4) -Specifically note the activities that require use of the hands; note the specific types of hand movements (e.g., pinching, gripping) required for these activities -Understanding of a patient’s occupational history is best obtained through a patient and/or caregiver interview with open-ended  questions(4)
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Functional limitations/assistance with ADLs/adaptive equipment -What assistive or adaptive equipment is available to the patient at home? Can it still be used based on patient’s current level of functioning?(4) -Document both high-  and low-tech  adaptations and equipment(4) -Patient’s functional status can be classified according to the American College of Rheumatology Classification of Global Functional Status in Rheumatoid Arthritis(4,5)completely able to perform usual activities of daily living (self-care,  vocational and avocational)(4)able to perform usual self-care  and vocational activities but limited in avocational activities(4)able to perform usual self-care  and vocational activities, but limited in vocational and avocational activities(4)limited in ability to perform usual self-care,  vocational, and avocational activities(4)
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives, caregivers, etc.(4) -Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?(4)

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting.) The following tests and measures relate specifically to occupational hand therapy for patients with RA; for information on a full occupational therapy assessment for patients with RA, see Clinical Review… Rheumatoid Arthritis (Occupational Therapy) , referenced above
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess the patient’s need for and/or use of assistive and adaptive devices to determine the devices that are most appropriate and will best serve the patient’s needs; incorrect use of devices can increase risk of falls(1) -Grip strength, pinch strength, and overall muscle strength(7) -Extent of joint involvement, including ROM, pain, deformities, etc.(7) -Patient’s personal preferences and willingness/readiness to use a specific device(7) -Cost; patient’s ability to afford the device(7) –Devices frequently incorporated into hand therapy for individuals with RA -Bathroom equipment -Grab bars next to the toilet/shower(4) -Shower chairs, bars, and/or benches(4) -Raised toilet seat(4) -ADL/IADL aids -Reachers; long-handled  equipment(7) -Shoe horn(4) -Elastic shoelaces(4) -Dressing sticks; sock aids(4) -Modified eating utensils(4) -Adaptive writing instruments(7) -Adaptive kitchen and cooking equipment(4) -Adaptive/ergonomic computer/mouse/keyboard(7) -Text-to-speech  software(4) -Ambulation aids -Does the patient require ambulation aids? Is the patient required to weight bear through hands to use the device(s)?
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess pulse bilaterally; note any discrepancies or abnormalities –Patients with RA commonly experience chills, numbness, and tingling in the hands and feet; however, these are usually due to impingement of nerves rather than poor circulation(1,5)Circumference measurement for joint swelling, if presentAssess proper body mechanics with functional mobility to assist in energy conservation  –An ergonomic assessment of the workplace might be indicated for patients with RA desiring to maintain employment status or return to work(8) -Adaptations of the work environment and specific job responsibilities might be necessary for a person with RA to continue to be employed and able to work comfortably(8) –The Ergonomic Assessment Tool for Arthritis (EATA) is a comprehensive assessment that can identify areas of need and provide guidance for appropriate ergonomic accommodations in the workplace(8)
relevant tests and measures.functional mobility: Assess as appropriate; utilize FIM for objective measurement
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: GaitAssess and document integrity, stability, mobility, and deformity of the joints in the hand and wrist(4) –Document mobility in each of the patient’s affected joints; assess flexion, extension, abduction, adduction, and rotation as appropriate given the specific joint(1) -Joint involvement in RA is usually symmetrical; however, some patients experience an asymmetrical pattern of joint involvement(1) –Note pain at rest and with movement of the joints(1) -Painful joints are often held in flexion to maximize joint volume and minimize distension of the joint capsule(1) –Document presence and location of crepitus (popping or cracking sound of the joint) as well as which movements cause it(4) –Document presence and location of rheumatoid nodules(4) –Document presence and extent of any joint deviations (change in normal joint position)(4) –Document presence and location of joint deformity as assessed by observation and palpation; this information can be compared to both past and future evaluations to document change over time(1,4) -Nodes are bony enlargements that indicate joint damage from osteoarthritis; these can also occur in patients with RA(4) –Document the extent and location of inflammation and/or synovitis(1,4) -Effusion is excess fluid in the joint capsule; seen as fusiform swelling that conforms to the shape of the joint(4) -Boggy swelling is thin and full of fluid and feels puffy, spongy, and soft to the touch; seen in acute/chronic-active  stages of RA(4) -Chronic synovitis is firm to the touch because the joint fills with synovial tissue(4) –Assess joint instability by applying stress to the individual joints in medial/lateral and anterior/posterior directions; document the location of unstable joints(4) if not acutely inflamed –Note the presence of contractures; these can occur from prolonged limitation of joint ROM(1) -Contractures result from adhesions that form during periods of joint pain and subsequent disuse(1)reliable and valid assessment of the use of joint protection strategies in patients with mild to moderate hand and upper limb joint involvement due to RA(9)Assess fine and gross motor function of the upper extremities and hands, as well as coordination; describe the quality of movement(1) –It is impossible to estimate the extent of a patient’s hand function based only on the appearance of the hand; patients with significant joint deformities can sometimes perform very well on both formal and informal assessments of hand function(4) -Arthritis Hand Function Test (AHFT)(1) -Cochin Rheumatoid Hand Disability Scale(1) -Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH) Outcome Measure(1) -For more information on the DASH, see Clinical Review… Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH) Outcome Measure ; CINAHL Topic ID Number 903177 -Jebsen-Taylor  Hand Function Test(4)  -Box and Block Test(29) -Was shown to have good inter-  and intra-rater  reliability in a pilot study in an Asian Indian population with RA -Michigan Hand Outcomes Questionnaire (MHQ)(1) -Sequential Occupational Dexterity Assessment (SODA)(1,10)
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: MMT to evaluate strength in both upper extremities; do not perform MMT with contracted muscles or muscles with tone and coordination issues(3,4) –For patients with arthritis, strength testing differs from normal procedures; resistance is applied at the end of range of pain-free  motion rather than the true end of the patient’s ROM(4) -Additionally consider joint protection principles when applying resistance and discontinue resistance completely if the patient experiences pain(4) –Patients with RA often have reduced muscle strength and endurance, and sometimes muscle atrophy as result of disuse(1) –Appropriate dynamometers can be used to obtain grip strength and pinch strength values(4) -A sphygmomanometer might be more comfortable than a standard dynamometer. With sphygmomanometers grip strength values may be impacted by hand size, but there are correlations between measurements using sphygmomanometers and Jamar dynamometers(11) -Strength and function of the muscles can fluctuate with joint stiffness(1)
observation inspection palpation includi: Note any signs of skin breakdown, especially if the patient wears a splint/orthosis
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: AROM and PROM will be impaired in joints affected by RA; AROM will likely be more affected than PROM(1,4) –Assess ROM using goniometer to measure the amplitude of the movement of the joints, if possible(3,4) -Can be difficult on a hand with joint deformities(4) -Assessing composite flexion, composite extension, and thumb opposition might be more of a functional measurement of the ROM of the hand.(4) Measuring the distance from the digit tip to the distal palmar crease can also be used to assess digit flexion –Note joint stiffness or instability during ROM testing(4) -Hard end-feel  in the presence of contracture indicates bony blockage -Firm end-feel  in which there is still some give to the joint indicates that the joint capsule or ligaments are limiting the ROM(4) –Patients with RA frequently have reduced ROM due to disuse and pain of the joints(1) -Limitations in ROM for patients with RA can result from ankylosis (lack of joint mobility), subluxation (volar or dorsal displacement of joints), and dislocation (the articulating surfaces of the joints are no longer in contact)(1,4)Assess safety and ability to perform ADLs hair, upper-  and lower-body  dressing, clothing management, using the toilet, applying makeup or shaving the face, bathing, eating –RA significantly limits an individual’s ability to perform ADLs and IADLs(1) -Reduced hand strength and dexterity from joint deformity and instability in patients with RA will impact all ADLs and IADLs(1) –Decreased strength and progression of RA can negatively impact ability to complete ADLs. Instruction in compensatory techniques can improve functional ability. The addition of exercise to an education program was not shown to improve reported ability to complete ADLs more than education alone in an RCT. The addition of exercise did not impact disease progression(12) –The Functional Independence Measure (FIM), the Assessment of Motor and Process Skills (AMPS), the Kohlman Evaluation of Living Skills (KELS), the Disability Rating Index (DRI), the Klein-Bell  Activities of Daily Living Scale (Klein-Bell),  the Performance and Satisfaction in Activities of Daily Living (PS-ADL),  and the Barthel Activities of Daily Living Index are appropriate standardized measures for ADLs in patients with RA.(3) The Manual Ability Measure (MAM) is another measure of functional upper extremity use that is appropriate with this population(25,26)  –For high-functioning  patients, assess IADLs such as driving (including car transfers), meal preparation, shopping, and housework -Patients with RA who are parents of young children will have a unique set of IADLs needs such as carrying/lifting the child; feeding, dressing, and bathing the child; diaper changing; physical play with the child; discipline; and homework help(13) -Lawton and Brody Instrumental Activities of Daily Living Scale -Includes items related to using the telephone, taking public transportation, shopping, meal preparation, housework, and medication and money management
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Sensation is often impaired in patients with RA(1,3,4) –Tactile and proprioceptive sensation is most often affected in this population(1) -Impairments of sensation can be due to impingement of the nerve due to soft tissue loss(1) –General sensory testing includes light touch (e.g., Semmes-Weinstein monofilaments, WeinsteinEnhanced Sensory Test [WEST]) pain, temperature, tactile localization, and two-point  discrimination(3) –Provocative tests, such as Phalen’s test and Tinel’s test, can be used in the case of suspected carpal tunnel nerve compression(4) –With known or suspected cervical spine involvement, assess light touch, sharp-dull  touch, and proprioception(4)
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Occupational performance measures(3) -Assessment of Occupational Functioning (AOF)(3) -Satisfaction with Performance Scaled Questionnaire (SPSQ)(3) -Occupational Performance History Interview II (OPHI II)(3) –Quality of life -RA can significantly affect the patient’s quality of life due to the impact on daily activities, socialization, and overall health(14) -The Short Form Health Survey (SF-36)  evaluates overall independence, emotional and mental health, limitations to previous roles, and social status; it is valid, reliable, and sensitive for the RA population(14) -Health Assessment Questionnaire (HAQ)(10) -Arthritis Self-Efficacy  Scale (ASES)(15) -The Canadian Occupational Performance Measure (COPM) evaluates function through evaluation at baseline and status throughout treatment, utilizing the patient’s direct input in the scale(3,4) -The COPM allows patients to identify goals in therapy that are personally meaningful; useful for a client-centered approach to therapy(4)

contraindications precautions: Exercise in short, frequent (i.e., 3 to 5)sessions throughout the day versus one long session
To avoid fatigue, alternate activities
Stop activity when fatigue and pain develop
Decrease the level of activity or remove the activity from the program if pain lasts for more than 12 hours after the end of the activity
During flares of the disease, increase rest; inflamed joints are damaged easily
Resume exercise routine gradually when flare subsides
Avoid deformity positions
Change positions every 2030  minutes throughout the day to avoid static positioning
When possible, use larger and stronger muscles and larger joints during activities
Avoid high-impact  sports and contact sports
Increased pain and joint inflammation may occur if therapy is overly aggressive
Stretching techniques should not be performed on swollen joints
Heavy resistance should not be used if it causes joint stress
Joint mobilizations should not be performed on inflamed joints

There must be a balance between prevention of contractures and adhesions with stretching and mobilization on the one hand, and the protection of the joint capsule, ligaments, and tendons that are weakened by the disease on the other

other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies
General recommendations for therapeutic intervention for patients with RA(5,16)
In general, patients with RA can have unstable vascular reactions to heat and cold; therefore, monitoring the patient carefully during the use of these modalities is essential(4)

Prior to the use of physical agents and modalities, the treating therapist must have specific training and education in the proper use and safe delivery of these modalities beyond entry-level  preparation(4)

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Hand therapy (or therapy to address hand issues) is an essential part of rehabilitation for patients with RA due to the significant impact of hand dysfunction on ADLs and IADLs(1)
assessment plan of care.rule out: The differential diagnosis of RA includes ankylosing spondylitis(5) chronic Lyme arthritis(2) crystal-induced  arthritis(5) –gout –pseudogout(5) human parvovirus B19 infection(2) enteropathic arthritis(5) osteoarthritis(2) paraneoplastic syndrome(2) psoriatic arthritis(2,5) spondyloarthropathies(5) systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)(2) septic arthritis
prognosis: There is no cure for RA; however, treatment methods can improve symptoms and functioning for patients with RA(1) –When RA is untreated, it causes significant disability and shortened life expectancy, primarily due to cardiovascular issues(2)
Both physical and functional outcomes are difficult to predict with RA(1)
The onset of RA is most often gradual, but it can also present abruptly(1)
RA is cyclical in nature, with exacerbations and remissions(1)

Features of RA that appear to have prognostic significance include: –the number and length of remissions(1) –the levels of RF in the blood(1) –presence of rheumatoid nodules(1,4) –the extent of bone erosion visualized radiographically at the initial evaluation(1) –sustained disease activity for more than 1 year(1)
Rheumatoid arthritis is associated with increased comorbidity, which negatively impactsfunctional outcome (18)

Work disability is a common long-term  consequence of RA. Factors associated with work disability claims include level of baseline disability and non-joint-related manifestations of systemic disease:(19)

Many approaches, including cognitive-behavioral  therapy, expressive writing, and mindfulness-based  intervention, havebeen associated with improved pain management and functionin patients with RA. Early intervention may improve the effectiveness of these treatments(20)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines PT for ambulation, gait training, lower extremity strengthening/ROM program, etc.(1) (unless addressed by treating PT hand therapist) Otolaryngologist (ENT) and/or speech-language  pathologist (SLP) to address hoarseness, if present(1) Registered dietician to improve nutritional intake and body composition(1) Wound care nurse or specialist if signs of pressure ulcers are present Case management or social worker to address emotional, home, and/or equipment and financial needs and provide support(1) Psychiatrist or psychologist if the patient has signs of anger, depression, or distress(1) –The authors of a study conducted in the United Kingdom to assess the psychosocial impact of inflammatory arthritis from the patient perspective found that although patients would like psychological support in the areas of symptom management, emotions, and work and leisure activities, they are infrequently asked by clinicians about social and emotional issues. The results are based on the responses of 1210 patients (53% of the patients who received the survey) who completed a questionnaire(30)
treatment summary: Patients with RA can benefit from therapy (e.g., hand therapy, occupational therapy)that includes education, self-management  strategies, and exercise (21,32) –The authors of a systematic review found that occupational therapy intervention helps patients maintain functional ability, slows the progression of deformities, and improves patient knowledge of the disease process and coping strategies to maintain independence and engagement in meaningful activity (e.g., work, self-care,  avocational activities)(21)

Authors of a critical appraisal of systematic reviews assessing OT interventions for RA published between 2007 and 2013 found evidence to support the use of therapeutic exercise (aerobic and resistive), patient education (adaptive equipment use, joint protection), and splinting, but not tai chi(28) –Six systematic reviews were critically appraised by the authors –Strong evidence was found to support therapeutic exercise. The type and intensity of exercise must be determined based on patient-specific  factors (e.g., pain, level of joint pathology). Both resistive and aerobic exercise are safe –There was strong evidence to support patient education on joint protection. The authors recommend that clinicians document the method of delivery of the education and that additional research into the efficacy of specific programs is warranted –There was some evidence to support the use of splints during flare-ups  to decrease pain and for increasing grip strength; however, the authors suggest that additional research is needed to further support the efficacy of splinting (e.g., type of splint, wearing schedules, patient compliance) and that clinicians should clearly document the goals for splinting using measurable outcomes
The authors of a 2018 systematic review were uncertain if exercise improved hand function or pain. They concluded that exercise probably improves function (medium and long term)(33)

Specific interventions will vary according to level of hand impairment and patient goals and characteristics (e.g., comorbidities, age, prior level of function, medical/surgical intervention[s], motivation for therapy), but can include the following: –Hand exercises(4) -There is no exercise program that is universally appropriate for patients with RA; all exercise programs must be specifically tailored to the needs of a given patient(4) -Exercise programs for patients with RA should avoid unnecessary joint stress, pain, and joint swelling and should work within the patient’s comfortable ROM(4) -Train the patient to perform each exercise slowly, smoothly, and with proper technique; additionally, educate the patient on the rationale for each specific exercise(4) -Strengthening upper and lower extremities with resistance (isometric or isotonic) as indicated by physician order; not appropriate for acute phase(4) -Discontinue any resistance exercise if the patient reports pain, the exercise creates deforming forces, or the exercise compromises joint stability(4)  -Grip-strengthening  exercises can be performed with light resistance putty for the joints in the hand(4) -Active or passive stretching can be incorporated to increase joint mobility; not appropriate for acute phase(4) -Specific hand ROM exercises utilized for patients with RA -Forearms/wrists(4) -With elbows partially bent and kept down toward the side of the body, turn the palms up and down -Lift the hands backward, allowing the fingers to curl, then bend the hands down, allowing the fingers to straighten -Fingers(4) -Instruct the patient to make a fist, then open the hands and straighten the fingers -Touch the thumb tips to the tip of each finger -With the palms on the thigh or against a table, move the thumbs away from the fingers and slide each finger toward the thumb –ADLs/IADLs(3,4) -Introduce assistive and/or adaptive equipment to increase safety and independence with ADLs/IADLs(4,22) -Incorporate frequent rest breaks into ADLs/IADLs(22) -Gradually increase the demands placed on the patient for ADLs/IADLs(4,22) -In general, patients with RA should not engage in activities that require the hand to be in a static position for a prolonged period of time(4) –Orthosis fabrication (i.e., splinting)(1,3,4) -Indicated for reducing inflammation, decreasing pain, supporting unstable joints, limiting undesirable joint motion, increasing ROM, and properly positioning joints(4) -A resting hand orthosis is very common in the treatment of RA(4) -Orthosis fabrication can be utilized appropriately in all phases and stages of RA(4) -Stage I (early): resting orthoses for decreased inflammation and pain as well as joint protection(4) -Stage II (moderate): day orthoses to provide comfort; night orthoses to relieve pain and/or protect joints against deformity; splints created to increase ROM(4) -Stage III (severe): day orthoses to promote increased function; night orthoses for positioning and comfort(4) -Stage IV (terminal): day orthoses to promote increased function; night orthoses for positioning and comfort(4) -Special considerations for use of orthoses in patients with RA include: -The added weight of the orthosis can put additional stress on the upper extremity, resulting in pain and fatigue; ensure that the orthosis is as lightweight as possible(4) -Forces are transferred from the splinted to adjacent, unsplinted joints, which can cause these joints to become more symptomatic(4) -Skin tolerance can be problematic because of the increased risk of fragile skin in patients with RA(4) -Patients with sensory impairments will need close monitoring when using an orthosis to identify signs of pressure(4) -Modify straps as needed to allow for increased ease and decreased joint stress when donning and doffing(4) -The authors of a study designed to assess the functional impact of a wrist splint inpatients with RA found improvements in manual dexterity for both light and heavy activities (23) -Examples of orthoses -Resting hand orthosis(4,24) -Indications: rest during acute flares -Considerations: immobilizes the entire hand; typically worn while asleep and majority of waking hours; should be taken off for hygiene/ROM -Although the benefits of resting hand orthoses are well-established,  studies have shown that patient compliance is only about 50%(4) -Wrist orthoses (e.g., cock-up  wrist orthosis) (4,24) -Indications: minimize pain  -Considerations: 10° to 15° of wrist extension to facilitate use of the hand (fingers are not immobilized); can be helpful to stabilize the wrist during heavier activities such as ironing, gardening, or housework(24) -Metacarpophalangeal ulnar deviation orthosis(4,24) -Indications: to align and support joints for functional tasks in an effort to minimize pain -Considerations: can restrict/interfere with hand use and ability to perceive sensory input; therapist needs to set wearing schedule -Swan-neck  orthosis(4,24) -Also known as a PIP hyperextension blocking splint; providesthree points of pressure to reduce PIP hyperextension. They can be fabricated from thermoplastic materials or purchased (e.g.,silver ring splints) -Indications: to restrict unwanted PIP hyperextension; allows for improved hand function -Considerations: can be custom-fabricated  for short-term/trial  use; prefabricated/commercial swan-neck  orthoses also available -Hand-base  thumb orthosis(4,24) -Indications: supports the thumb metacarpophalangeal and/or carpometacarpal joints to reduce pain and facilitate function -Considerations: wrist has fair amount of movement -Boutonniere orthosis(4) -Indications: for flexible boutonniere deformities; to block the PIP in extension and allow the DIP to flex -Considerations: create direct pressure over the dorsum of the PIP; skin must be monitored closely; patients sometimes reject these splints because they limit PIP flexion/reduce hand function -Silicone-lined  digital sleeves and pads(4) -Indications: protect painful nodes or nodules from external trauma –Pain and swelling management(3) -Rest(4) -Rest is a way for a patient with RA to reduce both pain and inflammation(4) -Rest can be indicated for the entire body, or achieved locally through splinting or avoiding/modifying activity to allow rest for a specific joint(4) -During phases of active systemic inflammation, 8 to 10 hours of sleep with periods of rest in the afternoon are recommended for patients with RA(4) -Thermotherapy and cryotherapy(1,4) -Can be helpful for management of pain as well as maintaining or improving the patient’s ROM(4) -Thermotherapy can increase blood flow, relieve pain, and increase tissue elasticity; however, it is possible for thermotherapy to increase inflammation as well, so do not use thermotherapy with acutely inflamed joints(4) -Thermotherapy can be delivered through hot packs, paraffin, fluidotherapy, and hydrotherapy in a heated pool or warm shower/bath(4) -Cryotherapy can be delivered through ice packs or gel packs -Gentle ROM exercises(1) –Assistive and adaptive equipment(3,4) –Education -Patient education -Energy-conservation  techniques: pacing oneself and balancing activity with rest breaks(1,3,22) -Joint protection strategies(1,4,22) -Respect pain(4) -Maintain muscle strength(4) -Maintain joint ROM, use each joint in its most stable and anatomical/functional plane(4) -Avoid positions of deformity(4) -Use the strongest joints possible for each task(4)  -Ensure the correct pattern of movement in activities(4) -Avoid prolonged static positions(4) -Avoid participation in activities that can’t be stopped immediately if they become too stressful(4) -Balance activity with adequate rest(4) -Reduce the force and effort used in all tasks (with assistive devices as needed)(4) -Family/caregiver education(3) . maintenance or prevention: There are no known measures to prevent RA; however, research has associated certain environmental factors with a decreased risk of developing RA(6) Moderate alcohol consumption may be associated with risk of RA(6) Long-term  breastfeeding and long-term  hormone replacement therapy or oral contraceptive use have been associated with decreased risk of RA(6) Although research studies have examined whether vitamin D, oral contraceptives, and red meat have an effect on risk for RA, there have been no consistent conclusions(6)
patient education: Education about the disease process is an extremely important part of occupational therapy for patients with RA. Education has been found to increase patients’ self-efficacy  and lead to improved use of disease management behaviors(3,4) Provide education about: –the basic underlying pathology of RA(4)  –prolonged synovitis, which can lead to irreversible joint damage/disability(4) –how to monitor the signs and symptoms of RA(4) –how to modify tasks if pain or fatigue sets in(4) –community and online resources for RA(4)

Caregiver education is important for carryover of ADL/IADL training into the home environment; provide the patient’s family with a plan for maximizing home safety for ADLs/IADLs with environmental modifications as appropriate(3,4)
